content: The Act may be cited as the "St. Augustine 450th Commemoration Commission Act of 2007". The founding of St. Augustine in 1565 established the first permanent European colony in the New World, creating a multicultural society with influences from Spain, England, Europe, Native Americans, and Africans. The city's institutions developed over 4.5 centuries continue to impact the United States and cross-cultural relationships. The National Park Service, State of Florida, city of St. Augustine, and University of Florida collectively own significant resources related to the history of St. Augustine. The city has existed since 1565 and is responsible for planning the 450th anniversary commemoration. A committee has been created for this purpose. The purpose of the Act is to establish the St. Augustine 450th Commemoration Commission. The Augustine 450th Commemoration Commission aims to ensure a national observance of the 450th anniversary of St. Augustine, cooperate with Florida's programs, provide a great visitor experience, and recognize the history of all peoples in St. Augustine. The Augustine 450th Commemoration Commission aims to recognize the history of all peoples in St. Augustine, support international involvement, assist in marketing efforts for commemorative activities, and promote heritage tourism and economic benefits for the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "commemoration," "Commission," "Governor," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT. The St. Augustine 450th Commemoration Commission is established. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is responsible for planning and executing programs to commemorate the 450th anniversary of the founding of St. Augustine, Florida. They will facilitate related activities nationwide, encourage various organizations to participate in anniversary events, coordinate research and publications about St. Augustine, and ensure the success of the anniversary celebration. The Commission is tasked with ensuring the 450th anniversary of St. Augustine provides a lasting legacy and public benefit by developing programs and facilities. They must prepare a strategic plan, annual performance plans, and a final report by December 31, 2015, detailing their activities, funds, findings, and recommendations. The Commission must prepare a final report by December 31, 2015, detailing their activities, funds, findings, and recommendations. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 16 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives recommended by the St. Augustine City Commission and the Governor, an employee of the National Park Service, the Mayor of St. Augustine, an employee of the State University System of Florida, and five nonresident individuals. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives recommended by the St. Augustine City Commission and the Governor, an employee of the National Park Service, the Mayor of St. Augustine, an employee of the State University System of Florida, and five nonresident individuals. These nonresident individuals must have an interest in, support for, and expertise appropriate to the commemoration, appointed by the Secretary with consideration of Congress' recommendation. Initial appointments must be made within 120 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission unless a designee is appointed. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives recommended by the St. Augustine City Commission and the Governor, an employee of the National Park Service, the Mayor of St. Augustine, an employee of the State University System of Florida, and five nonresident individuals. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A member appointed to fill a vacancy serves for the remainder of the predecessor's term. If a member appointed as Mayor of St. Augustine or from specific organizations ceases their position, they can continue on the Commission for up to 30 days. Meetings are held at least 3 times a year or at the call of the Chairperson or majority of members. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives recommended by the St. Augustine City Commission and the Governor. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission shall act only on an affirmative vote of a majority of its members, with a quorum constituted by a majority. The Secretary appoints a Chairperson, considering recommendations from the Governor. Members serve without compensation, except for Federal employees. Members of the Commission appointed by the Secretary serve without compensation, except for Federal employees. They are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 7. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint and dismiss an executive director and additional personnel as needed. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and their compensation can be determined by the Chairperson without following certain provisions of the United States Code. The maximum pay rate for the executive director and staff members is specified. The director and personnel's compensation shall not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of title 5, United States Code. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission on a reimbursable or non-reimbursable basis as requested. Any reimbursement received shall be credited to the agency's appropriation. The Commission may accept voluntary and uncompensated services, reimburse the State for detailed personnel, and receive administrative support services from the National Park Service on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. This section does not override the authority of the State, National Park Service, or city of St. Augustine regarding the commemoration. The Commission has powers, including the ability to procure temporary services at specified rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission, and its authority does not override that of the State, National Park Service, or city of St. Augustine regarding commemoration. The Commission has the authority to accept donations, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions by members or employees, and procure supplies and services to carry out its duties related to St. Augustine's historical significance in the United States. Any contracts or agreements made by the Commission cannot extend beyond its termination date. The Commission has the authority to make grants, provide technical assistance, and conduct research related to the early history of St. Augustine. It can also use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 2015. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for this Act will not expire and remain until expended.
